Authors:
GOVINDAN KRISHNAMOORTHY, SUGANYA KANNAN, MURUGAN
MARUDHAMUTHU
Title:
Novel bioactive compound from Aspergillus terreus DMTMGK004
contributes to the potential anti-pathogenic effect
Keywords:
antioxidant; anti-pathogenic metabolite; Aspergillus
terreus; extracellular polysaccharide; secondary metabolites; time
killing assay
Abstract:
Fungi particularly filamentous fungi are well known for
their secondary metabolite production. Aspergillus terreus was a notable
producer of a large number of biomolecules like lovastatin, terrein,
terreic acid and itaconic acid. Pneumonia is a major respiratory disease
caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Klebsiella pneumoniae and Hemophilus
influenzae. The present study focused on the evaluation of fungal
metabolite for their anti-pathogenic potential against pneumonia
infection. Soil samples were collected from various geographical regions
of Madurai district for causative fungi further fungal strain was
isolated and identified as Aspergillus terreus DMTMGK004. Secondary
metabolites were extracted from the fungi, further antioxidant and the
anti-proliferative potential was evaluated. Fungal metabolite exhibited
significantly high anti-proliferative property against AGS gastric
cancer cell line. Antimicrobial activity against K. pneumoniae, S.
pneumoniae and H. influenzae were analyzed and the MIC values were
determined. In addition, time-killing assay clearly illustrated that the
compound was able to eliminate more than 50% of the pathogens within
littlest hours of the treatment. From the spectral data, the functional
groups present in the compound were determined as carbonyl group and
phenolic hydroxyl group which constitutes for its bioactivity. The
compound depreciates the production of both exopolysaccharide and
capsular polysaccharide significantly. It also induced cell membrane
damage which leads to protein and nucleic acid leakage from the
pathogens. Hence, the results of the present study could provide a
better insinuation towards the formulation of new drugs for targeting
respiratory pathogens.
